document.docTitle: Structure and activity of a novel robust peroxidase from Alkanna frigida cell culture

paragraph.docTitle:
Structure and activity of a novel robust peroxidase from
Alkanna frigida
cell culture

document.paragraph:
Saeed Soleimani Asl a
, Ali Asghar Karkhane
a
, Javad Zamani Amirzakaria
a

Kambiz Akbari Noghabi a
, Jaleh Ghashghaie

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation: National Institute for Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology , Tehran , Iran

document.paragraph:
b Laboratoire d’ Ecologie, Syst´ematique et Evolution (ESE), Universite
´de Paris-Sud, CNRS, AgroParisTech, Universite´de Paris-Saclay, 91400 Orsay, France
A R T I C L E I N F O

subSection.paragraph: Active site pocket
Callus
Functional stability
Peanut peroxidase
Suicide substrate
A B S T R A C T

Demands for peroxidases (POX)s with diverse physicochemical properties have steadily grown as more applications of POXs are demonstrated. Plants are among the best sources of versatile POXs, and plant biotechnology, as an agricultural hassle-free technology, promises to circumvent the limitations of natural resource exploitation and to address the demands. Following this trend, it was shown that POX production steadily increased during the 31-day subculture of
Alkanna frigida
(from Boraginaceae ) callus on Murashige-Skoog medium containing 2,4- dichlorophenoxyacetic acid (10 6 M) and kinetin (10 5 M). The purified cationic enzyme ( POXalf ) maintained its optimal activity over pH 4–7 for 2 years. It was resistant to H 2 O 2 high concentrations (IC50 = 543.7 mM) and showed high specific activity in the reaction with phenol (4320.5 AU mg 1 > 20-fold of HRP AU). Furthermore, the specificity constant ratio of guaiacol to phenol indicated a 100 times faster reaction of POXalf with guaiacol. However, in contrast to HRP, it had little effect on diazo derivatives of aniline and meta-diaminobenzene. Based on the resulting primary structure from the tandem mass analysis, the POXalf 3D structure was constructed via homology modelling. Despite the high topological similarity between the HRP and POXalf structures, there were important differences between the active site pockets that could explain the observed differences in the corresponding substrate spectra and the specific activities. Considering the dynamics of POXalf production, its inactivity towards IAA and its high affinity for guaiacol, POXalf may have associated roles with
A. frigida
cell wall construction and monolignol metabolism.
* Corresponding author.
E-mail addresses: Kamahl@nigeb.ac.ir, Kamahlh@gmail.com (K. haghbeen).

Considering the booming applicability of POXs and the growing demands for versatile types of these enzymes, the production of a novel POX from the cell culture of
Alkanna frigida Boiss. (Boraginaceae)
( POXalf ) was studied.
A. frigida
is a Boraginaceae plant with the ability to produce both phenolic acids and naphthoquinone derivatives in its root ( Monsef-Esfahani et al., 2012 ). Callus induction occurs easily in its root explants, and the production of POXalf steadily increases as the subculture of the cells ages. The essential physicochemical properties of this enzyme are presented and discussed in the context of its 3D structure.

Callus induction gradually occurred after Day 7 of implantation of the root explants of
A. frigida
on solid MS medium. The resulting cells proliferated on the same medium in darkness at 25 ◦ C ( Fig. 1A ), with an average growth of 280% ( Fig. 1B ). The results were quantified ( Fig. 1C ) by using a standard curve (activity unit versus mg of the enzyme, Fig. S1A ) for commercial HRP. Fig. 1C reveals the remarkable POX content of the
A. frigida
callus compared with the other 4 calluses. This could be a result of either higher activity, higher production of POXalf or a combination of both factors.

The dynamics of POXalf production were studied in the context of catalase (CAT) activity in
A. frigida
calli at different time intervals after the subculture, as they both deal with H 2 O 2 . Fig. 1D shows that CAT gradually left its role to POXalf . As a result, POXalf production increased throughout the subculture. A similar phenomenon was also observed during the proliferation of
Ocimum basilicum
calli ( Mohammadnejad et al., 2021 ). In contrast to the disproportionation action of CAT on hydrogen peroxide, as shown in Equation (1), POX is able to host different organic molecules as electron donors. Therefore, in addition to water, a pair of organic radicals are also produced during a catalytic cycle of POX, see Equation (2). This capability allows POXalf to support both the developmental phenomena and the active biosynthetic processes of
A. frigida
cells during growth and ageing on solid culture ( Shigeto and Tsutsumi, 2016 ).
Catalase
Peroxidase

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 1. A)
A. frigida
callus at the end of a 31- day subculture and B) its corresponding growth profile. C) POX production in the calluses of
A. frigida
[A.f],

[A.e],
Lithospermum officinale
[L.o],
Onosma dasytrichum
[O.d], and
Nonea caspica
[N.c]. D) POX (filled columns) and CAT (dashed columns) activities in the extract of
A. frigida
callus during a 31-day subculture. The subcultures were carried out on solid MS medium containing kinetin (10 μM), 2,4-D (1 μM), and sucrose (5% w/v) in darkness at 25 ◦ C. See the experimental section for the enzymatic assays conditions.

Fig. 2. A) SDS-PAGE of purified POXalf [lane1: Ladder, lane2:HRP, lanes3,4&5: POXalf ] stained by Coomassie blue (left) and silver nitrate (right). Chromatograms of POXalf purification on B) size exclusion column [Sephadex G50, pH 6] and C) ion-exchange column [S-Sepharose, pH 6, NaCl 0.2 M]. D) UV–Visible spectrum of purified POXalf . (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the Web version of this article.)

Table 1 Quantified summary of POXalf purification from fresh
A. frigida
callus (120 g).

tableNote.paragraph: b SP: Specific activity was calculated by using ε = 6500 cm 1 M 1 for the 516 quinone-imine product ( Farhadi and Haghbeen, 2011 ).

subSection.paragraph:
The yields of POX production by the hairy roots of
Daucus carota
(2.1 U mg 1 ),
Ipomoea batatas
(15.6 U mg 1 ), and
Solanum aviculare
(7.6 U mg 1 ) were reported on the basis of the total proteins of the corresponding raw extracts (5.8, 6.5, and 4.9 mg g 1 of the fresh root, respectively) using guaiacol in the assay measurements ( Araujo et al., 2004 ). Regardless of the different substrates used in the activity assays, these data can be compared with the data in the first row of Table 1 , indicating an approximately 2-fold higher protein content of the roots with POX activities, at least one-third of that of POXalf . As comparable data, the production of peanut POX ( POXpnt ) is also noteworthy. An enzyme yield of 3.8 μg g 1 of cells was reported for cationic POXpnt after proliferation of the peanut cells in a suspension culture for 14 days. This gives a pure POXpnt yield of 7.6 mg kg 1 peanut cells with a specific activity of 1477 U mg 1 (in the presence of guaiacol) over one month ( Sesto and Huystee, 1989 ) versus 2 mg of pure POXalf per kg of
A. frigida
callus with a specific activity of 4320.5 U mg 1 (in the presence of phenol) after a 31-day subculture ( Table 1 ). These data show the remarkable specific activity of POXalf, which is rooted in the kinetics specifications demonstrated below.

heading.emphasis: 2.3.1. MW, optimal pH and thermal stability

subSection.paragraph:
In parallel with the structural analysis results (presented in the next section), an average molecular weight of 33.5 ± 1 kD was determined for POXalf from its SDS – PAGE analysis ( Fig. 2A ). This is close to the MW of the cationic POXs of
Eruca vesicaria
leaves (34 kD) ( Nadaroglu et al., 2013 ) and the
Nicotiana tubacum
cell culture (34 kD) ( Narita et al., 1995 ). Two-dimensional gel isoelectric focusing (2-D gel IEF, Fig. 3A ), revealed that POXalf was a mixture of several cationic POXs with close MWs and PI ranging from 9 to 10. A similar range of PI was reported for some other cationic POXs, such as garlic (
Allium sativum L
) POXs ( Marzouki et al., 2005 ) and POX isozymes obtained from the cell culture of tobacco ( Narita et al., 1995 ).

The optimal pH of POX activity may vary from one substrate to another because the changes in pH influence the redox potentials of both the substrate and the intermediate I [oxyferryl haem (Fe IV ––O) cation radical], which is formed after a reaction of H 2 O 2 with a POX ( Hayashi and Yamazaki, 1979 ). Fig. 3B indicates that POXalf showed its optimal activity at pH 5.5 and maintained 75% of its optimal activity between pH 4.5 and 7 in the presence of phenol. Changing the substrate from phenol to guaiacol shifted the range of the optimal pH to 3.5 to 6, while there were no significant changes in the optimal activity. Although a few plant POXs, such as POX of
Jatropha curcas
leaves ( Cai et al., 2012 ), could maintain their optimal activities over a wider range of pH values, many plant POXs show sharp activity drops within a ≤1 unit change around the optimal pH, such as cationic POXs of
Brassica oleracea ( Thongsook and Barrett, 2005 )
and sorghum grain ( Dicko et al., 2006 ). It is also understood from Fig. 3C that POXalf tolerates high temperatures during the assay period, but it is not stable above 50 ◦ C ( Fig. 3D ), regardless of the substrate identity. Similar feedback to the temperature changes has been reported for many POXs, including those of sorghum grain ( Dicko et al., 2006 ) and
Eruca vesicaria ( Nadaroglu et al., 2013 )
. Examination of the shelf life of the POXalf solution at 4 ◦ C revealed its high stability at the examined temperature, as there was only a 15% decrease in the functional stability of the enzyme after 2 years ( Fig. 3E and F ).

caption.paragraph: Fig. 3. A) The 2-D gel IEF of POXalf . B) Optimal pH of activity, C) optimal temperature of activity, and D) the thermal stability of POXalf in the presence of phenol (●) and guaiacol (▴). The average of triple assays of POXsolution (stored at 4 ◦ C) activity in the presence of phenol on E) day 1 and F) day 720. All the phenol (8.6 mM) alf and guaiacol (5 mM) reactions were carried out in PBS (10 mM) in the presence of constant amounts of POXalf (65.35 nM) and H 2 O 2 (6.76 mM). Constant pH of 7 and 6 (for phenol and guaiacol, respectively) and constant temperature (20 ± 1 ◦ C) were applied when needed. POXwas maintained 10 min at the desired pH and alf temperature prior to the assays for the stability examinations.

subSection.paragraph: To examine the ability of POXalf to oxidize different types of substrates, synthetic phenolic, catecholic, guaiacolic, and aniline derivatives of the diazo dyes, illustrated in Fig. 4 , were reacted with POXalf in the presence of H 2 O 2 . Using this diazo skeleton allowed us to control both the structural and electronic changes in the derivatives. In addition, the course of the enzymatic reactions could be followed spectrophotometrically ( Mirazizi et al., 2018 ). These examinations revealed that POXalf was able to oxidize phenolic, guaiacolic, and catecholic azo derivatives ( Fig. S2 , Supplementary document). It has been demonstrated that HRP can oxidize all of the structures illustrated in Fig. 4 , including IV and V ( Mirazizi et al., 2018 ). However, the reactions of POXalf with monoamines (structure IV) were slow ( Fig. S2D , supplementary document), and reactions with structure V did not proceed. Unlike HRP but similar to cationic POXpnt , POXalf had little effect on indole-3-acetic acid (IAA) ( Fig. S2E , supplementary document). This suggests that POXalf might have no direct impact on the regulation of IAA homeostasis ( Savitsky et al., 1999 ). However, similar to other plant POXs, POXalf could easily oxidize ascorbate ( Fig. S2F , Supplementary document).

caption.paragraph: Fig. 4. General chemical structure of the examined diazo compounds in reactions with POXalf .

subSection.paragraph: The kinetic parameters of POXalf for phenol, guaiacol, H 2 O 2 and KCN are shown in Table 2 . This data promotes the practical importance of POXalf . A specific activity of 4320.5 AU mg 1 (in the presence of phenol) was reported for POXalf , which was approximately 20 times higher than the corresponding specific activity reported for commercial HRP (206 AU mg 1 ) ( Farhadi and Haghbeen, 2011 ). This high specific activity could be behind the significant difference between the POX activities illustrated in Fig. 1C . However, Table 2 shows the higher affinity of POXalf towards guaiacol with a fast rate of reaction. This gives guaiacol a specificity constant more than 100 times higher than that of phenol in its reaction with POXalf . These data reveal significantly different specific activities of POXalf compared with those of HRP and POXpnt ( Sesto and Huystee, 1989 ).

Similar to other plant type-III POXs, POXalf was inhibited at higher concentrations of H 2 O 2 as well as by KCN. However, the high IC50 value of H 2 O 2 revealed the remarkable functional stability of POXalf in the presence of this suicide substrate. The Km values of POXalf for guaiacol and H 2 O 2 are comparable to the Km values reported for cationic POXs of garlic (9.5 and 2 mM) ( Marzouki et al., 2005 ) and broccoli (8.8 and 9.73 mM) ( Thongsook and Barrett, 2005 ), respectively. Possible roles of cationic POXs in the metabolism of monolignols have been documented ( Takeda et al., 2003 ). Considering the dynamics of POXalf production ( Fig. 1D ), its inactivity towards IAA and its high affinity for guaiacol support the assumption that this cationic enzyme might have associated roles with
A. frigida
cell wall construction and the regulation of cell wall plasticity.

caption.paragraph:
Table 3 Alignment of the amino acid sequence of POXalf with HRP-C (PDB:1HCH), POXpnt (PDB:1SCH), POXsp , and
A. thaliana POX
(PDB:1PA2). The residues in light and dark shadows are common residues between 4 and 5 (all) shown sequences, respectively. See discussion part (2.4.3.4) for the underlined residues.

subSection.paragraph:
Mass analysis of POXalf , taken from the SDS-PADE spot ( Fig. 2A ), led to the identification of the peptide fragments that all belonged to plant POXs ( Table S1A , Supplementary document). Analysis of this data by X! Tandem (xtpcpp-mingwv0.4.27) revealed a 38.85% overlap between the abundant fragments and the cationic POX of
Salvia splendens
( POXsp ), Table S1B . In view of the mass analysis results (both full and partial digestions) and the alignment of the recognized peptides with the primary structure of POXsp (https://www.genome.jp/entry/up: A0A4D8ZTK7_SALSN), an amino acid sequence was identified for POXalf ( Table 3 ). The consistency of the resolved primary structure was controlled by amplification of the corresponding cDNA and finding the putative gene of the enzyme by using the designed specific primers for POXalf introduced in the experimental section (data not shown here). Analysis of the data shown in Table 3 shows that POXalf has a sequence identity and similarity of 47.1 and 63.4% with HRP, 84.3 and 91.1% with POXsp , 70.6 and 83.6% with POXpnt , and 49.3 and 68.8% with POX of
Arabidopsis thaliana
. Although a study of POXalf glycosylation was beyond the objectives of this research, Table 3 and the electrophoretic mobility of POXalf ( Fig. 2A ) indicate that POXalf is moderately glycosylated compared with HRP-C (approximately 10 kD) ( Spadiut and Herwig, 2013 ).

BLAST of the POXalf sequence against the protein database had 3 hits, including 1SCH ( Schuller et al., 1996 ), 5TWT ( Moural and Lewis, 2017 ), and 1PA2 ( Qstergaard et al., 2000 ) with a sequence identity of 70.65, 64.16, and 49.67% belonging to
A. hypogaea
(peanut),
Panicum virgatum
(switchgrass), and
A. thaliana
, respectively. Therefore, 1SCH was selected as the template for the homology modelling. Accordingly, 6 models were built with the genetic Algorithm 341 (GA341) score of 1.0. Although all of the predicted models had close discrete optimized protein energy (DOPE) scores close to 30000, the model with the least Modeller objective function (molpdf) score of 1571.79 was selected for POXalf ( Fig. 5A ). The structure was validated by ProSA tools. The Z score of the model (8.26) was in the range of the structures identified by X-ray diffraction ( Fig. S4A , Supplementary document). The Ramachandran plot of the POXalf model revealed that 96.22 and 2.40% of the amino acid residues were in favoured and acceptable conformations, respectively, while only 1.38% of the residues were experiencing steric strain ( Fig. S4B , Supplementary document). The quality of the model structure was further assessed by a Verify3D program that investigated the folding compatibility of the atomic Model (3D) with its own amino acid sequence (1D). The resulting profile of the residues ( Fig. S4C , Supplementary document) had scores between 0.1 and 0.71, while 97.95% of the residues had an average 3D–1D score > 0.2. The compatibility score > 0 in a VERIFY3D graph corresponds to an acceptable side-chain environment ( Eisenberg et al., 1997 ).

caption.paragraph: Table 2 Kinetics parameters of POXalf obtained from the analysis of the corresponding kinetics graphs (Fig. S3, Supplementary document).

Fig. 5. A) Approved 3D model of POXalf (residues 61–75 are 80% transparent). B) Topology of helices in 3D structures of POXalf and HRP (PDB:1HCH). C) Stereo environments of distal and proximal Ca ions in POXalf structure.
Fig. 6. A) RMSD and B) RMSF plots obtained from the analysis of MD simulations (120 ns) of POXalf model.

subSection.paragraph: The refinement of the selected model was carried out through 120 ns MD. The RMSD plot ( Fig. 6A ) revealed that the structure reached full stability in less than 90 ns. The refinement of the structural attributes of POXalf before and after MD is summarized in Table S2 (Supplementary document) and discussed below.

2.4.3.1. Overall fold of POXalf .
The core fold of plant POXs is similar due to the special topological arrangement of the 10 α- helices, designated by letters from A to J, but they are usually accompanied by some variable helices. For instance, there are two more short helices after helix B ( Fig. 5B , in salmon colour) in both the POXalf and HRP structures, while POXpnt contains only helix B ( Schuller et al., 1996 ). These differences make the total number of helices in plant POXs dissimilar, with 13 in POXpnt , 15 in POXalf and 16 in HRP ( Fig. 5B ). Key residues for the catalytic activity of a plant POX reside on helices B and F, which are located on two sides (distal and proximal, respectively) of the haem group ( Fig. 5A , in green colour). Although the β- strands do not play a significant role in the overall folding of plant POXs, a short antiparallel β- sheet is observed near the haem group, i.e., residues 174–176 and 209–211 in POXalf ( Fig. 5A , in purple colour) and 173–175 and 210–212 in POXpnt ( Schuller et al., 1996 ).

2.4.3.2. Disulfide bonds, salt bridge, and calcium ions. The functional stability of the POXalf solution at 4 ◦ C over 2 years is illustrated in Fig. 3E and F . Plant POX folding owes its stability to some structural elements that support the scaffold of the enzyme against the hydrodynamic pressure of the solution. Four conserved disulfide bonds and one salt bridge ( Table S2 , Supplementary document) remarkably decreased the degrees of freedom of the structural components of the enzyme. The disulfide bonds of C10–C90, C43–C48, C96–C289, and C175–C 200 in POXalf ( Fig. 5A in yellow colour) match the C11–C91, C44–C49, C97–C290, C176–C201 and C11–C91, C44–C49, C97–C301, C177–C209 bonds in POXpnt and HRP-C1, respectively ( Krainer and Glieder, 2015 ; Schuller et al., 1996 ). D98 and R 122 in POXalf also build the salt bridge (2.89 Å, Table S2 ) between the helix D and the adjacent loop. This is achieved by D99- R 123 in both POXpnt (2.82 Å) and HRP-C1 (2.90 Å).

Two Ca 2+ ions occupy 2 cavities, close to helices B and F, on both sides of the haem group ( Fig. 5A and C ). Both the distal and proximal calcium ions are surrounded by residues that provide them with favourable electrostatic interactions that work as local constraints and enhance the structural stability of the enzyme. Fig. 5C illustrates the surrounding residues of Ca ions in POXalf . Among these residues, D42 directly connects helix B to the distal Ca ion, and a similar role is played by T168 on helix F ( Fig. 5C ). Identical to HRP-C, D43, V 46, D50, S 52 in POXpnt are the surrounding residues of distal Ca 2+ , while T170, D214, T217, and D 222 in POXpnt ( Table S2 , Supplementary document) and T171, D222, T225, and D 230 in HRP-C encircle the proximal Ca 2+ ( Berglund et al., 2002 ). This evidence supports the idea regarding the conserved microenvironment of these ions in plant POXs.

2.4.3.3. Prosthetic group of haem (iron III protoporphyrin IX).
The haem group of a plant POX occupies the central space between helices B and F. It anchors to the protein skeleton by strong H-bonds of its propionate moieties with a few conserved residues. However, small differences are observed in the arrangements of the H-bonds. In POXalf , R 30 and R 174 produce strong double-interactions with each of the propionate moieties of the haem group ( Table S2 and Fig. 5A in purple). The stabilizing effects of these bonds are seen in the RMSF plot of POXalf ( Fig. 6B ). In fact, the impact of these interactions on the overall stability of POXalf is comparable with those of the salt bridge and Ca ions ( Fig. 6B ). A similar arrangement is observed in POXpnt , where R 31, S35, and Q175 participate in H-bonds with haem propionates (2.95, 2.86, and 2.98 Å, respectively), while S73 and R 75 stand further at distances of 4.76 and 4.03 Å ( Schuller et al., 1996 ).

The correct position of the haem in the active site of a plant POX is mainly tuned through interactions with the residing residues on helices B and F. Helix B, on the distal side, consists of approximately 13 amino acids, including conserved R 38, H42, and F40 (in HRP), which play essential roles in both the function and stability of haem ( Fig. 5A ) ( Veitch, 2004 ; Moural and Lewis, 2017 ). Helix F is located almost below the haem in the proximal section and provides the prosthetic group with the conserved H167 (in HRP). The possible roles of R 38, H42, and H167 (equal to R 37, H41, and H 168 in POXalf , Table S2 ) have been well discussed in the literature. However, the debates on possible roles of helix F have not been conclusive since the crystallographic data reveal larger variations in the number of total residues of helix F compared with that of helix B (e.g., 13, 15, and 7 in HRP, palm POX, and POXpnt , respectively) in addition to the variable helices after helix F (named F ′ , F ′′ , F ′′ 2, Fig. 5B in green) ( Moural and Lewis, 2017 ).

2.4.3.4. Active site pocket in POXalf. High topological similarity is observed among the structures of the active site pockets of plant POXs. The overlaid structures of HRP-C on 1PA2 and POXalf ( Fig. 7A and B ) indicate that there must be a significant overlap between the substrate spectra of these enzymes. On the other hand, reviewing the constructing amino acids of this region reveals important differences that can influence the affinity of the pocket as well as the final orientation of the substrate in the pocket. The strand comprised of residues 137–142, the loop hosting residue 68, and residues 178–179 on helix F ′ construct the entrance of the active site pocket ( Fig. 7A ). Reviewing the corresponding amino acids of these residues (underlined in Table 3 ) and the structural topology of these enzymes reveals important differences. For instance, in addition to dissimilarities in the amino acids of strands 137–142, the spatial position of F67 of HRP is occupied by P 68 in 1PA2 and POXalf ( Fig. 7B ). The striking difference between HRP and POXalf relates to the spatial position of helix F’, where F179 of HRP has been displaced by a polar residue (threonine) in POXalf ( Fig. 7B ). Although compositional and conformational variations can be considered when explaining the observed different activities of POXalf and HRP towards monoamines and meta-diamines (structures IV and V , Fig. 4 ), definitive explanations require NMR/X-ray crystallography results.

The production of POX steadily increases during a 31-day subculture of
A. frigida
cells. The purified enzyme showed interesting physicochemical properties, including high specific activity, optimal activity over a wide range of pH values, a long shelf life, and resistance to high concentrations of H 2 O 2 . Based on the mass analysis results, the 3D structure of POXalf was obtained via homology modelling. Despite high topological similarity among the structures of HRP, POXpnt and POXalf , there were important compositional and conformational differences in the active site pockets that could be considered to explain the observed differences in the corresponding substrate spectra and the specific activities.

4-Aminoantipyrine (4AAP), 2,4-dichlorophenoxyacetic acid, kinetin, and phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride (PMSF) were purchased from SigmaTM Chemical and Biochemical Company (St. Louis, MO, USA ). Guaiacol was from Fluka Chemie GmbH. Folin-Ciocalteu reagent, ABTS, and ammonium sulfate were purchased from Merck (Darmstadt, Germany ). Azo dyes ( Fig. 4 ) were synthesized as described previously ( Mirazizi et al., 2016 ). Solid Murashige and Skoog medium (MS) was prepared according to the literature using 8 g L 1 agar ( Puad and Wai, 2016 ).
Alkanna frigida Boiss. (Boraginaceae)
samples were collected from Sheikh Shab˜an (
32 ◦ 35 ′ 06.3 ′′ N
50 ◦ 36 ′ 02.7 ′′ E
) in Charmahal Bakhtiyari Province of Iran in mid-July, and the plant specimens were identified by the botanist of the scientific board of the Iran Research Institute of Forests and Range Lands, Professor Dr. V . Mozaffarian. The statistical analysis was performed using Microsoft Excel software, and the results are presented as the mean ± standard error.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 7. Superimposed 3D structure of HRP-C (in brown) on A) 1AP2 and B) POXalf. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the Web version of this article.)

subSection.paragraph:
Sterilized explants ( 2–5 mm ) of various tissues of
A. frigida ,
including roots, leaves, and stems, were placed on MS medium (pH 5.8) supplemented with sucrose ( 30 g L 1 ), 2,4-D (1 μM), and kinetin (10 μM) at 25 ± 2 ◦ C in darkness. The resulting callus from the root explant proliferated on MS medium containing the same phytohormones and sucrose ( 50 g L 1 ) in darkness at 25 ◦ C. The subculture period varied from 14 to 31 days according to the goals of the experiments. The biomass was calculated from the weight difference of the callus before and after drying at 37 ◦ C for 48 h.

heading.emphasis: 4.2. Profiles of POX and CAT activities

subSection.paragraph:
The proliferated
A. frigida
callus was sampled at different time intervals during a 31-day subculture. The samples were subjected to concomitant POX and CAT assays. First, at 4 ◦ C, pieces of fresh callus ( 1 g ) were crushed and ground in a porcelain mortar containing 3 mL of extraction buffer [Tris base (10 mM, pH 6.0) containing PMSF (0.55 μM)]. The resulting mixture was filtered, and the filtrate (100 μL) was immediately assayed spectrophotometrically (at 510 nm ) for POX activity in the presence of phenol (8.6 mM), 4AAP (39.4 mM), and H 2 O 2 (6.76 mM) in phosphate buffer solution (PBS 10 mM, pH 6.8) at 20 ◦ C. The extinction coefficient of the quinone-imine product ( 6500 cm 1 M 1 ) was used in the relevant calculations ( Mohammadnejad et al., 2020 ). A spectrophotometric assay of CAT activity (at 240 nm ) was carried out with 100 μL of the filtrate in PBS (10 mM, pH 6.8) containing H 2 O 2 (10 mM) ( Mohammadnejad et al., 2021 ). The standard curves [ Fig. S1 , Supplementary Document] obtained for commercial HRP-C [Merck (Darmstadt, Germany )] and CAT [Serva electrophoresis GmbH (D-69115 Heidelberg)] were used to calculate the results in terms of mg of POX and CAT per gram of wet callus. All spectrophotometric measurements were carried out using a UV/Visible Specord 50+ spectrophotometer (Analytik Jena, Germany ).

Fresh
A. frigida
calli ( 120 g ) were homogenized in 150 mL of Tris buffer (10 mM, pH 6.0) containing PMSF (0.55 μM). The tissue debris was removed by centrifugation (
8500 g
, 20 min at 4 ◦ C) using a Beckman Centrifuge, J-21 model. The pellet was washed twice using 90 mL of the same buffer. The resulting homogenate was saturated (80%) by ammonium sulfate and was maintained overnight at 4 ◦ C. The precipitated proteins were collected by centrifugation (
13000 g
, 4 min at 4 ◦ C) and then dissolved in 3 mL of PBS (10 mM, pH 6.0) for further experiments.

The protein solution of the previous step (2 mL) was chromatographed on a Sephadex G-50 column (5 × 15 cm , Pharmacia) using Tris (10 mM, pH 6.0) as the mobile phase. The output of the column was monitored spectrophotometrically at λ = 280 nm . The fractions were examined for POX activity. The selected fractions were pooled and passed through an S-Sepharose column (1 × 20 cm ) that had already been equilibrated with Tris buffer (10 mM, pH 6.0). The proteins were eluted with a stepwise gradient of NaCl (100–1000 mM) in the same buffer. The fractions (1 mL) were monitored at 280 nm and examined for POX activity. According to the resulting chromatogram, the selected active fractions were pooled and used in subsequent experiments.

The protein content of the desired solutions was measured by the Bradford method. PAGE and SDS–PAGE of the samples were performed according to the conventional Laemmli method using a resolving (12.5%) and stacking (4%) polyacrylamide gel at a constant electrophoretic field of 200 V. The protein bands were visualized by both Coomassie brilliant blue R250 and AgNO 3 staining methods. To perform high-resolution 2D gel electrophoresis, isoelectric focusing (IEF) was conducted as described earlier ( Farhadi and Haghbeen, 2011 ). The second dimension electrophoretic separation was carried out on a 12.5% gel according to the Laemmli method ( Laemmli, 1979 ).

Important physicochemical properties of the purified POXalf , including optimal pH, optimal temperature, thermal stability, operational stability, substrate spectrum (reactivity), inhibition, and relevant kinetics parameters, were measured spectrophotometrically in a conventional UV–visible quartz cell in a total volume of 3 mL using PBS (10 mM, at the desired pH) as the reaction medium using the desired organic substrate. In addition to phenol (mentioned above), guaiacol was also used as the organic substrate in some kinetics studies on POXalf . Subsequently, the formation of the chromophoric product ( ε = 26,600 cm 1 M 1 ) was followed at 470 nm ( Farhadi and Haghbeen, 2011 ). Additional information about the experiments is mentioned in the captions of the corresponding data. The kinetics parameters of the substrates were extracted from Lineweaver-Burk analysis of the corresponding velocity curves under steady-state conditions, and the inhibition constants were obtained from the fitted equations of the inhibition graphs as well as by using the Cheng–Prusoff equation ( Cheng, 2001 ): IC50 = Ki [1 + [S]/ Km ]. The results of the kinetic studies are the average of at least triplicate measurements. A unit of activity is equal to the formation of the chromophoric product (1 μM min 1 ).

heading.emphasis: 4.6.1. Protein digestion and tandem mass analysis

subSection.paragraph: For structural elucidation, the eluted POXalf from SDS – PAGE was reduced and digested by trypsin as previously described ( Shevchenko et al., 2006 ). Fifteen microlitres of the sample was injected into a Dionex Ultimate 3000 LC–MS/MS system coupled to a Q-Exactive mass spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Bremen , Germany ). For peptide LC separation, an Aeris peptide XB-C18 reversed-phase column (150 × 2.1 mm ; 1.7 μm; 100 Å; Phenomex, Le Pecq, France ) was used. The mobile phase consisted of phase A [water (LC–MS grade water) containing formic acid (0.1%)] and phase B [acetonitrile containing formic acid (0.1%)] that was delivered at a flow rate of 0.5 mL min 1 . The results were analysed using the X! TandemPipeline (version0.2.40).

Total RNA was extracted from frozen
A. frigida
callus powder by a TRIzol-like reagent ( Rio et al., 2010 ). An Invitrogen™ cDNA synthesis kit (Thermo Fisher Science, United States ) was used to synthesize cDNA. Then, the cDNA (5 μL) was amplified by PCR with the selected primers, designed based on the beginning and end peptides of the POXalf protein identified by mass spectrometry and the conserved domains of plant POXs obtained by BLASTn. The primers were:
Forward primer: 5-GCTGTTAACTCTGCGGTGTCG-3.
Reverse primer: 5-TTAGTTAGTTCTCCTGCAGTTCC-3.
The thermocycling conditions were 94 ◦ C (5 min) followed by 34 cycles at 94 ◦ C (30 s), 58 ◦ C (30 s), 72 ◦ C (1 min), and 72 ◦ C (10 min).

The 3D structure of POXalf was predicted via homology modelling by Modeller 9v19, while the 3D structure of POXpnt (PDB ID: 1SCHA) was used as the template ( Schuller et al., 1996 ). To evaluate the predicted 3D model structure, a Ramachandran plot was constructed using the PROCHECK server (http://services.mbi.ucla.edu/PROCHECK) through the SAVE server (http://services.mbi.ucla.edu/SAVES). The ProSA web server (https://prosa.services.came.sbg.ac.at/prosa.pHp) was used to calculate the Z score. The model structure was further evaluated with the VERIFY3D server by assessing the compatibility of each amino acid residue with the local 3D structure by averaging the 3D–1D score ( Eisenberg et al., 1997 ). Molecular dynamics (MD) simulation was used to refine the structures obtained from homology modelling. Structural refinement was performed using GROMACS 4.6.3. To run the simulation, previously reported conditions and settings for analysis were applied ( Ghofrani et al., 2021 ). See the Supplementary document for the experimental details. Visualization and analysis of molecular structures were performed by UCSF Chimera 1.10.2 and web-based iCn3D (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Structure/icn3d/full.html).

This manuscript is based on original research data that have not been published elsewhere. The authors declare that there are no conflicts of interest. All authors read and approved the final manuscript and agree to submission for publication.

Funding was provided by the National Institute for Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology (Project 730) in collaboration with Laboratoire d’ Ecologie, Syst´ematique et Evolution (ESE), Paris-Saclay University.

Ghashghaie: Resources, Supervision, Funding acquisition. K. Haghbeen: Conceptualization, Methodology, Resources, Supervision, Funding acquisition. All authors participated in the preparation and revision of the manuscript.
The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.
